conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.
You are Player RED.

<proposal count> 1 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> As Player RED, my goal is to sell the object X at a price that covers my production costs. I will start by proposing a price slightly above my costs to leave room for negotiation and to try to make a profit. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 45 </newly proposed trade>
<message> Hello Player BLUE, I have an object X for sale. Considering the production costs and the value of the object, I propose a price of 45 ZUP. I believe this is a fair starting point for negotiations. </message>

<other player message> Thank you for the offer, Player RED. I believe there's some room for negotiation here. How about we settle on 40 ZUP for the object X? It's a competitive price that takes into account market conditions and still offers you a profit. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 40 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count> 2 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has proposed to buy the object X at the cost price of 40 ZUP. While this covers my costs, it does not provide any profit. I want to counter-propose with a price that gives me a slight profit while still being reasonable to Player BLUE. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 42 </newly proposed trade>
<message> I appreciate your counteroffer, Player BLUE. However, selling at cost doesn't leave any margin for profit. Let's meet halfway between our initial proposals. How about 42 ZUP for object X? This price gives me a minimal profit and should still be acceptable for you considering the value of X. </message>

<other player message> Thank you for considering my position, Player RED. I understand your need for a profit margin. To continue our good-faith negotiation, I propose a price of 41 ZUP for object X. This adjustment reflects both our interests in achieving a fair transaction. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 41 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count> 3 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has come up by 1 ZUP to 41 ZUP, which is a compromise between our previous offers. This offer provides me with a small profit of 1 ZUP, which is lower than my previous counter but still acceptable. Considering the negotiation process and the willingness of Player BLUE to close the deal, it may be prudent to accept this offer to ensure a sale and avoid the risk of ending up without any profit at all. </reason>
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you for your proposal, Player BLUE. I agree that it's important for both sides to feel that the transaction is fair. I accept your offer of 41 ZUP for object X. Let's proceed with the trade. </message>
